meeting_annotations.speaker: Kristen Schell
meeting_annotations.transcript: I was just going to comment on that uh and uh maybe share some results from a recent paper that we've published. So I'm a uh systems modeler and we were looking at carbon capture and storage projects globally, but what we had data for were the 34 in the US that were uh let's see, projected to happen, said they were going to happen, but then they didn't happen. And so most of the uh storage or use of carbon that happens now and has been happening since the 70s is enhanced oil recovery to help produce uh oil from oil wells. Uh and one of the the problems as uh Greeshma was alluding to is like what what else can you do with it? So uh the carbon there has been carbon capture at some point sources, the most successful is at uh coal fired power plants, but still not everyone is doing it and the question is why? If it's the technology is there, uh why aren't we doing it? Uh and one of the sad cases was uh the the Petro Nova plant in Texas. They had been uh capturing carbon at the source and but just this February they stopped doing it because the price of oil was too low. So they have all the technology in place and it's just sitting there. Uh and one of the things that we found was that you you need a credible revenue stream for your CO2. It can't just be sequestering it. You need you need you need the company to make some kind of money off of it. So what kind of products can we make with this? I think is a really interesting question.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Chris Jones
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, the revenue stream could be tax credits for sequestering, right? So that's that's a model. Um, 45Q gives $50 a ton for that.
